iqm_definition:
AFNI'S outlier ratio. Mean fraction of outliers per fMRI volume, from AFNI's 3dToutcount.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

AFNI's quality index. Mean quality index, from AFNI's 3dTqual.
Values close to 0 indicate higher quality.

Coefficient of joint variation between white matter and gray matter.
Higher values indicate more head motion and/or intensity non-uniformity artifacts.

Contrast-to-noise ratio, reflecting separation between GM & WM.
Higher values indicate higher quality.
Number of volumes in the beginning of the fMRI timeseries identified as non-steady state.

DVARS is the average change in mean intensity between each pair of fMRI volumes in a series.
Higher values indicate more dramatic changes (e.g., due to motion or spiking).

DVARS is the average change in mean intensity between each pair of fMRI volumes in a series.
Higher values indicate more dramatic changes (e.g., due to motion or spiking).

DVARS is the average change in mean intensity between each pair of fMRI volumes in a series.
Higher values indicate more dramatic changes (e.g., due to motion or spiking).

Shannon entropy-focus criterion.
Higher values indicate more ghosting and/or head motion blurring.

Foreground-background energy ratio: the variance of voxels inside the brain divided by the variance of voxels outside the brain.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Mean framewise displacement: measure of subject head motion, which compares the motion between the current and previous volumes.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Number of timepoints with framewise displacement >0.2mm.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Percent of timepoints with framewise displacement >0.2mm.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Image blurriness (full-width half-maximum).
Higher values indicate a blurrier image.

Image blurriness (full-width half-maximum).
Higher values indicate a blurrier image.

Image blurriness (full-width half-maximum).
Higher values indicate a blurrier image.

Image blurriness (full-width half-maximum).
Higher values indicate a blurrier image.

Global correlation: Average correlation of all pairs of voxel time series inside of the brain. Illustrates differences between data due to motion/physiological noise/imaging artifacts.
Values closer to zero are better.

Ghost-to-signal ratio along the x or y encoding axes.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Ghost-to-signal ratio along the x or y encoding axes.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Intracranial volume fraction in CSF.
Values should move within a normative range.

Intracranial volume fraction in grey matter.
Values should move within a normative range.

Intracranial volume fraction in white matter.
Values should move within a normative range.

Intensity non-uniformity (bias field) median.
Values closer to 1 indicate higher quality; further from zero indicate greater RF field inhomogeneity.

Intensity non-uniformity (bias field) range.
Values closer to 1 indicate higher quality; further from zero indicate greater RF field inhomogeneity.

Mortamet's quality index 1. The proportion of voxels outside the brain with artifacts to the total number of voxels outside the brain.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Mortamet's quality index 2. A quality index accounting for effects of both clustered and subtle artifacts in the air background.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Residual partial volume error in CSF.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Residual partial volume error in grey matter.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Residual partial volume error in white matter.
Higher values indicate lower quality.

Signal-to-noise ratio within the tissue mask.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Signal-to-noise ratio within the CSF mask.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Signal-to-noise ratio within the grey matter mask.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Signal-to-noise ratio within the total mask.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Signal-to-noise ratio within the white matter mask.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Dietrich et al. (2007)'s signal-to-noise ratio in CSF.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Dietrich et al. (2007)'s signal-to-noise ratio in grey matter.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Dietrich et al. (2007)'s signal-to-noise ratio (total).
Higher values indicate higher quality.

Dietrich et al. (2007)'s signal-to-noise ratio in white matter.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

TPM overlap: How well the CSF tissue probability maps overlap with those from the MNI ICBM 2009 template.
Higher values indicate better spatial normalization.

TPM overlap: How well the grey matter tissue probability maps overlap with those from the MNI ICBM 2009 template.
Higher values indicate better spatial normalization.

TPM overlap: How well the white matter tissue probability maps overlap with those from the MNI ICBM 2009 template.
Higher values indicate better spatial normalization.

Temporal signal-to-noise ratio taking into account mean signal over time.
Higher values indicate higher quality.

White matter-to-maximum intensity ratio: captures skewed distributions within the WM mask, caused by fat and vascular-related hyperintensities.
Ideal values fall within the interval [0.6, 0.8].
